The twinkling stars announce the close of day,</br>And darkness gathers underneath our lee;</br>From toil the weary sailors haste away,</br>And leave the deck to solitude and me.
No sunbeam now illumes the trembling surge;</br>And all the ship a solemn stillness holds,</br>Save where the helmsman chants an artless dirge,</br>Or vigil hoarse the lapse of time unfolds.
Beneath my feet (while Night extends her shade),</br>Lull'd in the motion of the rolling deep</br>(Each in his narrow hammock closely laid),</br>The sons of Neptune share refreshing sleep.
As slow I pace, remembrance brings to mind</br>The early fate of many a seaman brave;</br>Whose mould'ring relics, suddenly consign'd</br>To dark oblivion, rest below the wave.
These hear the boatswain's busy call no more,</br>Nor climb the mast, our hoist aloft the sail;</br>No longer listen to the billow's roar,</br>Or spread the swelling canvas to the gale.
These filial love no more, alas!  shall greet,</br>No conjugal affection thee salute;</br>No child shall haste their wish'd return to meet;</br>No wife enjoy their honest labour's fruit.
For these the tender gush of grief has flow'd</br>Down many an anxious parent's furrow'd cheek;</br>The widow fainted under mis'ry's load,</br>And sireless orphans wept with sorrow meek.
Their daring souls dlsdain'd a foreign yoke;</br>The Gallic flag oft yielded to their might.</br>How bent the Hollanders beneath their stroke?</br>How haughty Spaniards felt their force in fight?
Ye lordlings!  slight not these with scornful thought,</br>Because in lowly rank they liv'd and died.</br>Since by their valour your defence was wrought,</br>And by their toil your luxury supplied.
The highest state, the pinnacle of pow'r,</br>Affords no shelter from the stroke of Death;</br>Reflect, that one inevitable hour</br>Alike deprives the prince and slave of breath!
The hardy tar unnumber'd perils wait;</br>Vain all that skill or valour can perform!</br>In many a shape he meets the stroke of fate,</br>Victim to hunger, fight, disease, or storm.
Ev'n now, perhaps, beneath us, as we pass,</br>The bones of many a valiant sea-man lie:</br>Whose gen'rous heart had grac'd superior class,</br>Whose daring hand had honour'd station high.
But merited promotion from their aim,</br>Was constantly withheld by adverse chance:</br>The want of int'rest still obscur'd their fame,</br>And lack of friends still thwarted their advance.
Full many an hero (though of common rank)</br>In ocean's breast has found a wat'ry tomb:</br>Who still the draught of disappointment drank,</br>And spent in toil and strife meridian bloom.
Some humble Nelson, that (had Fortune smil'd)</br>With great Trafalgar's victor might have vied;</br>Some Duncan brave (though not in peerage styl'd):</br>Some undistinguish'd Hawke may here abide.
To wear the glitt'ring badges of command,</br>And order culprits to the stripe at will;</br>To reap vast prizes by the lucky brand,</br>Each, mod'rate wish sufficient to fulfil;
Their lot forbade:  nor only barr'd the train</br>From wealth and sway, but often sav'd from guilt:</br>None of their tyranny could e'er complain,</br>No blood (except the foe's) by them was spilt.
Not their's the sateless thirst of sordid ore!</br>Not theirs of hypocrites unveil'd the shame!</br>Not their's the evils of unlawful store!</br>Or gnawing consciousness of hidden blame!
Within the wonted space of naval scenes</br>Their humble hopes and wishes still were bound:</br>Content on board they work'd to earn the means</br>Of future competence on British ground.
Yet, though no mark denote their place of rest,</br>No short inscription tell their name and date;</br>Yet many a relative in mournful breast</br>Preserves the sad remembrance of their fate.
When the ripe ears the sickle's aid require,</br>Loquacious reapers oft beguile their toil</br>By long account of brother, son, or sire,</br>Who perish'd distant from their native soil.
When winter's howling storms their rage display,</br>And round each blazing hearth the peasants throng,</br>The seaman's deeds, who died when far away,</br>Are still the theme of story or of song.
For who e'er ventur'd on the main to roam?</br>And brav'd the chance of storm or hostile ball?</br>Reckless of welcome at return to home,</br>Or hopeless of a tear, if doom'd to fall.
In his last pang, by this suggestion mov'd,</br>The death-struck sailor yields his passing soul:</br>Expiring he reflects on those he lov'd,</br>And seems to take the tribute of their dole.
But if (surviving many a bold compeer)</br>He reach the land for which he toil'd and fought;</br>With rapture clasp'd to many a bosom dear,</br>He shares a joy beyond the reach of thought.
There, at the foot of that aspiring tree,</br>Whose boughs erst nodded o'er his infant sport,</br>His listless frame, from care and sorrow free,</br>At noon-tide hour may gentler slumber court.
If maim'd, or blind, or crippled, he return,</br>His grateful country will not aid deny:</br>With ardent zeal the hearts of Britons burn,</br>To sooth his troubles, and to grant supply.
For thee (who pourest forth this artless strain)</br>The destiny that waits is yet unknown;</br>Perhaps — to perish on the stormy main!</br>Perhaps — at home to rest beneath a stone!
Welcome be either doom, if conscience clear</br>Yield hope of future bliss, and fear expel;</br>Yet (if on earth thy corse should find a bier)</br>Some frail memorial thus perhaps may tell:—

EPITAPH.</br>Here on Earth's bosom rests a son of grief,</br>Whose early prospects once were bright and gay;</br>But Fortune frown'd!  no friends bestow'd relief!</br>And disappointment mark'd him for her prey!
Yet through life's stormy scene unwreck'd he sail'd;</br>Nor felt the gripe of poverty and want:</br>For constant industry and toil avail'd</br>Of food and raiment to procure the grant.
He still refrain'd from censure and from praise,</br>Unblam'd and unapplauded let him bide!</br>Till the great Judge of all the dead shall raise,</br>And justly their eternal lot decide.</br>
